name: dedth2v
params: class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, wff w0, wff w1, wff w2, wff w3
body: -| wi(wceq(c0, cif(c0, c1, w0)), wb(w1, w2))
-| wi(wceq(c2, cif(c2, c3, w0)), wb(w2, w3))

stmt.origin: dedth2h(c0, c1, c2, c3, w0, w0, w1, w2, w3)
stmt.pretty: dedth2h(c0, c1, c2, c3, w0, w0, w1, w2, w3)

body.origin:
|- wi(wa(w0, w0), w1)
-| wi(wceq(c0, cif(c0, c1, w0)), wb(w1, w2))
-| wi(wceq(c2, cif(c2, c3, w0)), wb(w2, w3))
-| w3

cumulated.origin:
|- wi(w0, w1)
-| wi(wceq(c0, cif(c0, c1, w0)), wb(w1, w2))
-| wi(wceq(c2, cif(c2, c3, w0)), wb(w2, w3))
-| w3

comment: Weak deduction theorem for eliminating a hypothesis with 2 class variables. Note: if the hypothesis can be separated into two hypotheses, each with one class variable, then ~ dedth2h is simpler to use. See also comments in ~ dedth . (Contributed by NM, 13-Aug-1999.) (Proof shortened by Eric Schmidt, 28-Jul-2009.)
